questions.text: A 4-year-old boy with developmental delay and a behavioral history of self-injurious actions, including tongue biting and finger biting to the point of needing bandages, is brought to a pediatric neurologist. Based on the clinical presentation, which enzyme deficiency is most likely responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyl transferase.

 

Option B.

 

The combination of retardation and self-mutilation helps in arriving at the diagnosis of Lesch-Nyhan disease. 

 

Hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyl transferase (HGPRT) is part of the purine salvage pathway and its deficiency results in the inability to recycle purines ü°™ overproduction of uric acid. 

 

C/F- Mentally retarded, hyperuricemia, gout and engage in compulsive self-destructive behaviors.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cystathionine synthase: Deficiency results in homocystinuria, characterized by elevated urinary homocysteine. C/F- failure to thrive and visual problems due to lens displacement.  Also deficiency of methionine synthase, pyridoxine, folate, or vitamin B12 can cause homocystinuria.

 

Option C. Homogentisic acid oxidase: Deficiency results in alkaptonuria. C/F- dark urine and darkening of connective tissue (e.g., ear cartilage may appear bluish).

 

Option D. Hexosaminidase A: Deficiency causes Tay-Sachs disease ü°™ results in the accumulation of GM2 ganglioside. C/F-mental retardation, blindness with cherry-red spot on the macula and muscular weakness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lesch-Nyhan syndrome, a disorder caused by a deficiency in the enzyme hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyl transferase (HPRT), and its deficiency leads to the overproduction of uric acid and a host of neurological and behavioral abnormalities, including self-mutilation behaviors.

 

Ref: Lippincott 7/e: P 296-297.

choices.text: PRPP synthetase decreased activity can contribute to gout by increasing purine synthesis
Sodium urate crystals can deposit in kidneys and impair renal function
Uric acid overproduction is seen in myeloproliferative disorders like leukemia
Allopurinol used in treatment as it inhibits xanthine oxidase

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents to the orthopedic outpatient department with joint swelling and pain, as depicted in the image. The physical examination reveals swollen, erythematous joints with tenderness. Laboratory tests show elevated serum uric acid levels. She is diagnosed with gout. Which of the following statements regarding her condition is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. PRPP synthetase decreased activity can contribute to gout by increasing purine synthesis

 

Explanation:

 

  • Option A. PRPP synthetase decreased activity can contribute to gout by increasing purine synthesis ‚Äì Incorrect (Correct Answer)
    This is incorrect because decreased activity of PRPP synthetase reduces purine synthesis. In contrast, increased (not decreased) activity of PRPP synthetase leads to enhanced purine synthesis and overproduction of uric acid, contributing to gout. Therefore, the statement is wrong.

 

Other Options:

  • Option B. Sodium urate crystals can deposit in kidneys and impair renal function ‚Äì  True
    In chronic gout, urate crystals can deposit in the renal parenchyma and tubules, leading to urate nephropathy and potential renal failure.
  • Option C. Uric acid overproduction is seen in myeloproliferative disorders like leukemia ‚Äì True
    Leukemias and other myeloproliferative disorders involve rapid cell turnover and breakdown of nucleic acids, leading to hyperuricemia and secondary gout.
  • Option D. Allopurinol used in treatment as it inhibits xanthine oxidase ‚Äì True
    Allopurinol is a inhibitor of xanthine oxidase, reducing the conversion of hypoxanthine and xanthine to uric acid, making it effective for long-term management of gout.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

Understand that gout can result from overactivity of PRPP synthetase, leading to increased de novo purine synthesis and elevated uric acid production. Treatments like allopurinol target xanthine oxidase to reduce uric acid synthesis.

 

Ref: Harper 30 /e: p 354.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents to the clinic with the laboratory findings of reducing substances in his urine that are not glucose, signs of liver disease, and decreased liver glycogen observed in a liver biopsy. To identify the underlying cause of his symptoms, which of the following metabolite concentrations should be measured?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Uridine diphosphate

 

Option C.

                        

UDP-glucose is the activated form of glucose utilized for the synthesis of glycogen and Galactose.

 

It is formed from the reaction of glucose1-phosphate and UTP.

 

The conversion of galactose to glucose is at the UDP-sugar level, which is deficient in galactosemia.

 

UDP derivatives of glucose, galactose and sugar amines are key precursors for synthesis of cerebrosides and gangliosides.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Glucose 1-phosphate and Option B. Fructose 1,6-bisphosphate: The glucose or fructose phosphates regulates glycogen stores but will not prevent synthesis of glycogen or block galactose metabolism.

 

Option D. Cytosine diphosphate: It is important for the synthesis of phospholipids, thus forming high-energy CDP diacylglycerol which transfers diacylglycerol to form phosphatidylinositol’s (signal transducers) and cardiolipin (seen in mitochondrial membrane and develops antibodies in autoimmune disorders)

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of non-glucose reducing substances in urine and reduced liver glycogen, with elevated UDP-sugars, indicates a glycogen storage disease like GSD Type Ia. Diagnosing involves measuring UDP concentrations to reveal a block in the metabolic pathway involving glucose-6-phosphatase.

 

Ref: Harper 30 /e: p 116,177,201, 571.

questions.text: A research team is evaluating the effects of azaserine, a drug known to inhibit glutamine-dependent enzymes, on nucleotide synthesis. In considering the drug's impact on purine biosynthesis, Nitrogen atom at which position in the generic purine structure is Contributed by Glutamine?
questions.solution:
Ans. 9

 

Explanation:

 

Purine biosynthesis involves building the purine ring step by step on a ribose-5-phosphate backbone. Various atoms of the purine ring come from different precursors.

 

Glutamine provides nitrogen atoms via its amide nitrogen (-NH2) in the purine biosynthesis pathway.

 

In purine biosynthesis:

 

 

Thus, glutamine donates nitrogen at:

  • N3
  • N9

 

In the context of your question (specifically asking for ‚Äúthe nitrogen contributed by glutamine‚Äù), position 9 is one of the key sites.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 7: N7 comes from glycine, not glutamine. Glycine contributes two carbons and one nitrogen (C4, C5, N7).

 

Option C. 4: C4 comes from glycine as well. Glycine contributes to the entire C4-C5-N7 chain.

 

Option D. 1: N1 comes from aspartate, not glutamine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Purine biosynthesis is a multi-step process that builds the purine ring atom by atom using various precursors:
    • Glutamine‚Äôs amide nitrogen provides N3 and N9.
    • Glycine donates C4, C5, and N7.
    • Aspartate provides N1.
    • Formyl-THF (N10-formyl-tetrahydrofolate) donates C2 and C8.
    • CO2 (bicarbonate) supplies C6.
  • Inhibition of glutamine-dependent enzymes (like by azaserine) disrupts steps that require glutamine as an amide donor, blocking Nitrogen incorporation and thus halting purine biosynthesis.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e p 348-349.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a history of chronic alcohol abuse presents to the clinic with pain and swelling in the joints of his hands, as shown in the picture. The condition is characterized by the formation and deposition of sodium urate crystals in peripheral joints. Which of the following factors is known to contribute to the formation of these urate crystals?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Decreased temperature

 

Option A.

 

Hyperuricemia (gout) is a clinical condition characterized by elevated levels of uric acid that lead to the formation of sodium urate crystals.

 

Uric acid has a pKa of 5.4 and is ionized in the body to form urate, which is not very soluble in an aqueous environment and the quantity of urate in human blood is also very close to the solubility range.

 

So, any situations which leads to excessive degradation of purine bases can increase the urate concentration past the solubility point → formation of urate crystals.

 

The decreased body temperature seen in the joints contributes to the formation of urate crystals under these conditions.        

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Decreased blood flow: While decreased blood flow might theoretically lead to increased concentration of uric acid, it is not typically cited as a direct contributor to crystal formation. Gout flares are not commonly associated with decreased blood flow.

 

Option C. Exposure to sunlight: Sunlight exposure does not affect the solubility of uric acid and is not a recognized factor in the formation of urate crystals.

 

Option D. Increased blood flow: Increased blood flow would generally improve the elimination of uric acid through the kidneys and is not associated with the formation of urate crystals. However, increased blood flow can lead to the inflammatory response seen with gout flares once the crystals have formed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Decreased temperature can lead to urate crystal formation in peripheral joints is important for understanding why gout commonly affects the cooler distal joints and how acute attacks may be precipitated by changes in temperature.

 

Ref: Harper 30/esp. 354, Lippincott 7/ed: p 301.

choices.text: Competitive inhibitor of xanthine oxidase & decrease UA formation
Increase renal excretion of urate
Reduce body uric acid pool

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with sudden onset of severe pain in his right big toe, extending up to the knee, which began in the morning. The pain developed after a night of alcohol consumption. On examination, the affected big toe is swollen, tender, and warm. Laboratory tests reveal a serum uric acid level of 9.6 mg/dl. After being prescribed allopurinol by the physician, the patient's symptoms improved within three days. What is the mechanism of action of allopurinol in the treatment of hyperuricemia?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Competitive inhibitor of xanthine oxidase & decrease UA formation

 

Option A.

 

The patient is diagnosed to have Gout.

 

Allopurinol is a competitive inhibitor of xanthine oxidase → decreases the formation of uric acid. Xanthine and hypoxanthine are more soluble and are easily excreted.

 

Xanthine oxidase converts allopurinol to alloxanthin, which is a more effective inhibitor of xanthine oxidase.

 

This is a good example of ‘suicide inhibition'.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Increase the renal excretion of urate by decreasing the reabsorption of urate from kidney tubules: Action of uricosuric drugs. e.g., probenecid.

 

Option C. Reduce body uric acid pool: done by PEG (polyethylene glycol) uricase and conversion of urate to allantoin (more water soluble and easily excreted).

 

Option D. Arrest the arthritis: Action of Colchicine, an anti-inflammatory agent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Allopurinol is a structural analog of hypoxanthine. It acts as a competitive inhibitor of xanthine oxidase, an enzyme responsible for converting hypoxanthine to xanthine and xanthine to uric acid. By inhibiting this enzyme, allopurinol reduces the production of uric acid, thereby treating hyperuricemia which is often associated with gout.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e:  p 344.

questions.text: In the complex biochemical pathway of purine biosynthesis, certain substrates are crucial for the synthesis of the purine nucleotides. Among the following options, which compound is a necessary substrate for the initiation and progression of purine biosynthesis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 5-Phosphoribosylpyrophosphate (PRPP)

 

Explanation:

 

Purine biosynthesis starts with the formation of PRPP (5-Phosphoribosyl-1-pyrophosphate), a key activated ribose sugar donor.

PRPP + Glutamine ‚Üí 5-Phosphoribosylamine (the first committed step in purine biosynthesis).

  • PRPP is synthesized from ribose-5-phosphate by the enzyme PRPP synthetase.
  • It serves as the foundation onto which the purine ring is built step-by-step.

 

Thus, PRPP is essential at both initiation and progression stages.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 5-Methyl thymidine:

  • This is a nucleoside derivative of thymine (used in DNA), not involved in purine biosynthesis (purines = adenine & guanine).

 

Option B. Ara C (Cytarabine):

  • This is a chemotherapy drug, a cytidine analog used to inhibit DNA synthesis‚Äînot a substrate for purine biosynthesis.

 

Option C. Phosphoribosylamine:

  • This compound is an intermediate (formed after PRPP reacts with glutamine).
  • It's not a substrate to initiate purine biosynthesis, but a product of the first committed step.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Purine biosynthesis requires PRPP as a substrate.
  • The first committed step is catalyzed by glutamine-PRPP amidotransferase, converting PRPP ‚Üí phosphoribosylamine.
  • This sets the stage for ring assembly to eventually produce IMP (inosine monophosphate), the precursor of AMP & GMP.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 583.

questions.text: Which one of the nucleotide is first formed by the de novo purine biosynthesis:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Inosine 5’ monophospahte (IMP)

 

Option B.

 

The regulatory enzymes of Purine Synthesis are PRPP Synthase and PRPP Glutamyl Amido transferase.

 

The rate limiting step of de novo Purine Synthesis is PRPP Glutamyl amidotransferase

 

PRPP level determines the de novo purine synthesis, which activates PRPP Synthase.

 

The rate of PRPP Synthesis depends on the availability of ribose 5 Phosphate

 

AMP, ADP, GMP and GDP the end products of de novo Purine synthesis feedback regulate PRPP Synthase and PRPP Glutamyl Amidotransferase.

 

First Nucleotide formed in Purine Synthesis-Inosine Mono Phosphate (IMP)

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Adenosine 5’ monophosphate (AMP): AMP is synthesized from IMP and not directly formed during the initial steps of de novo purine biosynthesis.

 

Option C. Xanthine 5’ monophosphate (XMP): XMP is an intermediate in the pathway of purine metabolism but not the first nucleotide formed in the de novo synthesis of purines.

 

Option D. Guanosine 5’ monophosphate (GMP): Like AMP, GMP is derived from IMP and is not the initial product of the de novo purine biosynthesis pathway.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inosine 5’ monophosphate (IMP) is the first nucleotide produced in the de novo purine biosynthesis pathway. This pathway builds the purine ring molecule by molecule onto the ribose sugar. Once IMP is synthesized, it can then be further converted into other purine nucleotides, such as adenosine 5’ monophosphate (AMP) and guanosine 5’ monophosphate (GMP), through a series of specific enzymatic reactions.

 

Ref: Vasudevan 7/e: p 583.

questions.text: Which of the following correctly identifies the nitrogen sources for N3 & N9 positions in Purine Ring?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Amide nitrogen of glutamine

 

Option A.

 

CONTRIBUTORS OF PURINE RING:    

                                    

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Aspartate ‚Äì contributes N1 of PURINE ring.

 

Option C. Glycine - contributes N7 of PURINE ring.

 

Option D. N10 formyl THFA- contributes C8 of PURINE ring.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the biosynthesis of purines, the nitrogen atoms at positions N3 and N9 originate from the amide nitrogen of glutamine.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 347-348.

questions.text: In the context of infantile conditions, hypoglycemia is observed in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Both a and b

 

Explanation:

 

Both Glycogen Storage Disease Type I (GSD I) and Hereditary Fructose Intolerance (HFI) can lead to hypoglycemia, particularly in infants.

 

Option A: 

Glycogen Storage Disease Type I (Von Gierke Disease)

  • Caused by a deficiency of glucose-6-phosphatase.
  • This enzyme is crucial for the final step of gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis, converting glucose-6-phosphate to free glucose.
  • Without it, the liver cannot release glucose into the bloodstream ‚Üí severe fasting hypoglycemia, typically noticed shortly after birth.

 

Option B: Hereditary Fructose Intolerance (HFI)

  • Caused by a deficiency of aldolase B.
  • When fructose, sucrose, or sorbitol is introduced (e.g., via formula or weaning), fructose-1-phosphate accumulates, which:
    • Traps phosphate
    • Inhibits glycogenolysis
  • Leads to hypoglycemia and other symptoms like vomiting, hepatomegaly, and failure to thrive.

 

Note: HFI typically manifests after exposure to fructose-containing foods, so it may not present immediately after birth, but it is a cause of hypoglycemia in infants, especially during weaning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Be aware of metabolic disorders that can cause hypoglycemia in neonates or infants, particularly:

  • Glycogen Storage Disease Type I (Von Gierke)
  • Hereditary Fructose Intolerance (HFI)
  • Galactosemia
  • Medium-Chain Acyl-CoA Dehydrogenase Deficiency (MCAD)
  • Long-Chain Acyl-CoA Dehydrogenase Deficiency (LCAD)

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/e: 138.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with symptoms of excessive thirst, increased appetite, tiredness, and a thin build. He has been advised to undergo fasting blood sugar (FBS) and postprandial blood sugar (PPBS) tests and is currently 12 hours into his fast. During this period of fasting, which one of the following enzymes is likely to be phosphorylated and active?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hormone sensitive lipase      

 

Option D:

                                     

  • Hormone sensitive lipase of adipocytes are phosphorylated and activated by protein kinase A in response to epinephrine.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Arginase: Arginase is an enzyme involved in the urea cycle, which converts arginine into urea and ornithine. Its activity is not directly influenced by fasting or feeding states.

 

Option B. Fatty acid synthase: Fatty acid synthase is involved in the synthesis of fatty acids, a process that is downregulated during fasting when the body is mobilizing, rather than storing, energy.

 

Option C. Glycogen synthase: Glycogen synthase is responsible for glycogen synthesis in the liver and muscle cells. This enzyme is less active during fasting, as the body is breaking down glycogen stores, not building them.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hormone-sensitive lipase (HSL) is an enzyme in adipose tissue that breaks down stored triglycerides into free fatty acids and glycerol, which can then be used for energy. HSL is activated by phosphorylation in response to low insulin and high glucagon levels, which are typical during fasting. Thus, in a fasting state, HSL would be phosphorylated and active to facilitate the mobilization of fat stores.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e p 261-263

choices.text: Storage as fructose
Enters HMP shunt via ribulose-5-phosphate

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman, following a meal rich in carbohydrates, undergoes various metabolic adjustments to manage the influx of glucose. One of these adjustments involves the metabolism of glucose-6-phosphate, a key metabolite in glucose homeostasis. Considering the fed state, where glucose is abundant, what is the primary fate of glucose-6-phosphate in tissues?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Storage as glycogen

 

Option D:

 

In the fed state, the major fate of glucose-6-phosphate in tissues is its conversion and storage as glycogen. This process is essential for maintaining blood glucose levels within a narrow range, especially during periods of fasting.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Storage as fructose is not a primary pathway for glucose-6-phosphate metabolism in tissues during the fed state.

 

Option B: Glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate is an intermediate in glycolysis, but the direct storage of glucose-6-phosphate as glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate is not a primary fate in the fed state.

 

Option C: While glucose-6-phosphate can enter the Hexose Monophosphate (HMP) shunt, this pathway is primarily active in specific tissues like the liver, and its main function is not for storage but for producing NADPH and ribose-5-phosphate for biosynthetic reactions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The uptake of glucose into the liver GLUT 2 is independent of insulin.
  • In the well fed state → concentration of glucose entering the liver increases → increased rate of synthesis of glucose-6-phosphate.
  • This is in excess of the liver’s requirement for energy-yielding metabolism. So, it is used mainly for synthesis of glycogen.
  • In both liver and skeletal muscle, insulin acts to stimulate glycogen synthase and inhibit glycogen phosphorylase

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p148.

questions.text: Which of the following tissues is INCAPABLE of contributing directly to blood glucose levels through glycogen breakdown?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Muscle

 

Option B:

 

Muscle tissue stores glycogen for its own use and lacks the enzyme glucose-6-phosphatase, which is required to convert glucose-6-phosphate into free glucose that can be released into the bloodstream. Therefore, glycogen breakdown in muscle leads to glucose-6-phosphate being used primarily within the muscle cells themselves for energy, particularly during exercise, rather than contributing to systemic blood glucose levels.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Liver: The liver is capable of contributing directly to blood glucose levels through glycogen breakdown. It contains the enzyme glucose-6-phosphatase, which allows for the conversion of glucose-6-phosphate into free glucose that can be released into the bloodstream, thereby maintaining blood glucose levels, especially during fasting.

 

Option C. Both: This option is incorrect because the liver can directly contribute to blood glucose levels through glycogen breakdown, while muscle cannot.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 Differences between Liver Glycogen and Muscle Glycogen.

 

 

Muscle glycogen is not directly available as a source of blood glucose because muscle lacks glucose-6-phosphatase which releases free glucose from glucose 6-P.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e p177, 178.

choices.text: Enzyme located in the endoplasmic reticulum
Inhibited by albumin in the cytoplasm

questions.text: A 7-year-old child with frequent hypoglycemic episodes during fasting is being evaluated. Laboratory findings indicate normal glycogen structure but impaired glycogenolysis. Given the critical role of Glucose-6-Phosphatase in this process, why isn't Glucose-6-Phosphate immediately converted to glucose in hepatocytes?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Enzyme located in the endoplasmic reticulum

 

Option C:

 

Glucose-6-Phosphatase, which catalyzes the final step in glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis by converting Glucose-6-Phosphate into glucose, is located in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) of hepatocytes. This necessitates the transport of Glucose-6-Phosphate from the cytoplasm to the ER, a process mediated by specific translocases, before it can be dephosphorylated. This spatial separation serves as a regulatory mechanism to control glucose release into the bloodstream.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Only active during gluconeogenesis: This is incorrect because Glucose-6-Phosphatase is active during both gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis, not exclusively during gluconeogenesis. Its activity is crucial for maintaining blood glucose levels, especially during fasting.

 

Option B. Requires Protein Kinase activation: Glucose-6-Phosphatase activity is not directly regulated by protein kinases. The regulation of this enzyme is primarily through substrate availability and its subcellular localization, rather than through activation by phosphorylation.

 

Option D. Inhibited by albumin in the cytoplasm: There is no direct interaction between albumin and Glucose-6-Phosphatase that would inhibit its activity. Albumin, a serum protein produced by the liver, primarily functions in maintaining oncotic pressure and transporting substances; it does not play a regulatory role in glycogenolysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Glucose-6-phosphatase is in the lumen of the smooth endoplasmic reticulum
  • Glucose-6-phosphate is transported to SER by a transporter known as translocase to be acted by Glucose- 6-phosphatase.
  • Genetic defects of the Glucose-6-phosphate transporter can result in a variant of type I glycogen storage disease.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e p178.

questions.text: Approximately how many hours does it take for liver glycogen stores to become significantly depleted in an average adult under normal physiological conditions?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 18 hours

 

Option B:

 

Explanation:

 

Under normal physiological conditions, liver glycogen stores can sustain blood glucose levels for about 18 hours of fasting. After this period, the body increasingly relies on gluconeogenesis and the breakdown of fats for energy, marking a transition in the body's primary energy sources to maintain metabolic functions during prolonged fasting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Liver and Muscle Glycogen are generally exhausted by 18 hours of fasting.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e p149.

questions.text: An 18-year-old medical student, immersed in the demanding schedule of clinical rotations, often finds himself skipping lunch and dinner. To sustain his energy levels and cognitive function during these prolonged periods without food, his body must mobilize glucose from liver stores. Which enzyme plays a pivotal role in this process by facilitating the release of glucose from glycogen stored in the liver?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Glycogen phosphorylase

 

Option C:

 

Glycogen phosphorylase is the key enzyme involved in glycogenolysis, the process of breaking down glycogen into glucose-1-phosphate, which is then converted to glucose-6-phosphate. This can be further processed to release free glucose into the bloodstream, particularly from the liver, thereby maintaining blood glucose levels during fasting states or periods of high energy demand. This enzyme is thus crucial for providing the necessary glucose to the body, especially when dietary intake is insufficient or delayed, as in the scenario described.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A.  Acetyl-CoA carboxylase: This enzyme is involved in fatty acid synthesis, not in the mobilization or release of glucose from glycogen stores.

 

Option B. Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase: This enzyme is part of the pentose phosphate pathway and is involved in producing NADPH and ribose-5-phosphate, rather than in the direct mobilization of glucose from stored glycogen.

 

Option D. Glycogen synthase: This enzyme is responsible for the synthesis of glycogen from glucose, the opposite process to what is needed in this scenario, where the goal is to mobilize glucose from glycogen stores.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glycogen is the storage form of glucose, which is an easily mobilizable fuel store. When individuals are deprived of or reduced intake of carbohydrates, the body responds by breaking down glycogen stores in the liver in order to maintain normal blood glucose levels. The two main enzymes involved in the degradation and synthesis of glycogen are glycogen phosphorylase (option c) and glycogen synthase (option d), respectively. 

 

The processes of glycogen synthesis and degradation are coordinated by a hormone-triggered cascade that ensures that when one enzyme is active, the other enzyme is inactive.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 177-180.

questions.text: A 1-year-old child is brought to the outpatient department by their parents due to concerns of muscle hypotonia, failure to thrive, and an enlarged abdomen. Laboratory tests reveal hypoglycemia and ultrasonography shows hepatomegaly. Following a comprehensive evaluation, the child is diagnosed with a type of glycogen storage disease (GSD). In the context of GSD, the glycogen content in the liver is not influenced by which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Dietary Riboflavin levels

 

Explanation

 

Dietary riboflavin (vitamin B2) levels do not directly influence glycogen content in the liver in the context of glycogen storage diseases (GSDs).

Riboflavin serves as a precursor for flavin mononucleotide (FMN) and flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD), which function as cofactors for various oxidation-reduction enzymes. While riboflavin is essential for many metabolic processes, it does not play a direct regulatory role in glycogen synthesis or breakdown in the liver.

Glycogen storage diseases are inherited metabolic disorders caused by enzyme deficiencies in glycogen synthesis, breakdown, or regulation pathways. The clinical presentation described in the question (muscle hypotonia, failure to thrive, enlarged abdomen, hypoglycemia, and hepatomegaly) is consistent with several types of GSD.

The regulation of hepatic glycogen content primarily depends on hormonal and metabolic factors that directly control glycogen synthesis (glycogenesis) and breakdown (glycogenolysis).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serum glucose levels - This is incorrect as a choice for factors that do NOT influence glycogen content. 

 

Serum glucose levels directly affect hepatic glycogen metabolism. High blood glucose promotes glycogen synthesis through activation of glycogen synthase, while low blood glucose levels trigger glycogen breakdown to maintain normoglycemia.

 

Option B. Insulin levels - This is incorrect as a choice for factors that do NOT influence glycogen content. Insulin is a key hormone that promotes glycogen synthesis in the liver by:

  • Activating glycogen synthase (via dephosphorylation)
  • Inhibiting glycogen phosphorylase
  • Increasing glucose uptake and its phosphorylation to glucose-6-phosphate

 

Option C. Glucagon Level - This is incorrect as a choice for factors that do NOT influence glycogen content. Glucagon has effects opposite to insulin on hepatic glycogen. It promotes glycogenolysis (glycogen breakdown) by:

  • Activating glycogen phosphorylase via a cAMP-dependent protein kinase cascade
  • Inhibiting glycogen synthase

 

Educational Objectives:

 

In glycogen storage diseases, liver glycogen content is regulated primarily by glucose levels, insulin, Glucagon and factors affecting these parameters (like dietary amino acids).

choices.text: Proglucagon is synthesized in α cells of islets of Langerhans
It is a straight polypeptide chain with 29 amino acids
It activates the enzyme glycogen phosphorylase

questions.text: Which of the following statements about glucagon is INCORRECT?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Stimulates glycogen synthesis. 

 

Option C:

                         

  • It is a polypeptide hormone with 29 amino acids.
  • It is secreted by the alpha cells of pancreas as proglucagon precursor.
  • t½: 5 minutes and inactivated in the liver.
  • An increase in blood glucose level inhibits secretion of glucagon.
  • Mainly glycogenolytic → active form of glycogen phosphorylase is formed under the influence of glucagon.
  • Depresses glycogen synthesis

 

other options :

 

Option A. Proglucagon is synthesized in α cells of the islets of Langerhans: This statement is correct. Proglucagon is indeed synthesized in the α cells, and through post-translational modifications, glucagon is produced.

 

Option B. It is a straight polypeptide chain with 29 amino acids: This statement is also correct. Glucagon is a peptide hormone composed of 29 amino acids.

 

Option D. It activates the enzyme glycogen phosphorylase: This is true. Glucagon activates glycogen phosphorylase, an enzyme involved in glycogenolysis, thereby promoting the breakdown of glycogen into glucose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glucagon, a hormone produced by the α cells of the islets of Langerhans in the pancreas, plays a crucial role in glucose metabolism. Its primary function is to raise blood glucose levels by promoting glycogenolysis (the breakdown of glycogen to glucose) and gluconeogenesis (the synthesis of glucose from non-carbohydrate sources). Therefore, the statement that glucagon stimulates glycogen synthesis is incorrect, as it actually promotes glycogen breakdown.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 322

questions.text: Glycogenin is often discussed in the context of glycogen synthesis, but there is a common misconception about its nature. Considering the biochemical role of glycogenin, is it accurate to classify it as a polysaccharide?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) FALSE

 

Option B:

 

Glycogenin is not a polysaccharide; it is actually a protein that serves as a primer for glycogen synthesis. Glycogenin autocatalytically attaches glucose molecules to itself, starting the glycogen synthesis process, which is then extended by glycogen synthase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Glycogenin is a 37 kDa protein (POLYPEPTIDE).
  • Glycogenin catalyses transfer of 7 glucosyl residues from UDPGlucose, in alpha 1 → 4 linkage. Thus, glucosyl residues are added on specific tyrosine residues of Glycogenin.
  • Glycogenin remains at the core of the Glycogen granule.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e p177.

questions.text: In the management of certain leukemias, a specific drug is utilized for its ability to interfere with the synthesis of nucleic acids, crucial for the proliferation of rapidly dividing cells. This drug achieves its therapeutic effect by inhibiting a key pathway in purine metabolism, indirectly affecting DNA replication. Which of the following medications is being described?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 6 mercaptopurine

 

Option A:

 

6-Mercaptopurine is an antimetabolite that interferes with purine nucleotide synthesis and metabolism, leading to the inhibition of DNA and RNA synthesis. This effect is particularly useful in the treatment of certain types of leukemia, where it can inhibit the proliferation of rapidly dividing leukemic cells by interfering with nucleic acid synthesis, thus indirectly inhibiting DNA replication.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Actinomycin D binds to DNA and inhibits RNA synthesis by preventing RNA polymerase from moving along the DNA, primarily affecting transcription rather than DNA replication directly.

 

Option C: Puromycin interferes with protein synthesis by causing premature chain termination during translation, which does not directly impact DNA replication.

 

Option D: Rifampicin inhibits bacterial RNA polymerase, thus affecting bacterial transcription. It is used primarily as an antibiotic and does not directly inhibit DNA replication in cancer cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inhibitors of DNA replication:

 

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 586.

choices.text: Lesch-Nyhan Syndrome: Disorder of pyrimidine metabolism
Lesch-Nyhan Syndrome: Disorder of purine metabolism
Primary Gout: Deficiency of Salvage Pathway
Secondary Gout: Due to tumour lysis syndrome

questions.text:
A 6-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother, who is concerned about her son's repeated lip and finger biting and involuntary upper limb movements. She recalls noticing an orange discoloration in his diaper as an infant. Upon examination, the boy has multiple bite marks on his fingers and lips, and laboratory tests reveal a serum uric acid level of 9.5 mg/dl:

 

 

Based on the clinical presentation and laboratory findings, what is the most probable diagnosis, and which metabolic pathway is affected in this disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Lesch-Nyhan Syndrome: disorder of purine metabolism

 

Option B.

 

Lesch-Nyhan Syndrome: an X-linked inherited disorder of purine metabolism.

 

Due to deficiency of HGPRTase → the rate of salvage pathway is decreased → accumulation of PRPP and decreased inhibitory purine nucleotides.

 

C/F: Self-mutilation, mental retardation, excessive uric acid, nephrolithiasis, and Gout (later life).

 

Treatment:  Allopurinol. Since the salvage pathway is deficient, it is effective only to inhibit xanthine oxidase.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Lesch-Nyhan Syndrome: Disorder of pyrimidine metabolism: This is incorrect because LNS is associated with purine, not pyrimidine, metabolism.

 

Option C. Primary Gout: Deficiency of Salvage Pathway: While gout involves hyperuricemia, the self-mutilating behavior and early onset are not typical of primary gout and indicate a more complex disorder like LNS.

 

Option D. Secondary Gout: Due to tumor lysis syndrome: Secondary gout can occur due to increased cell turnover, as seen in tumor lysis syndrome, but it does not explain the neurological and behavioral symptoms, nor is it common in children without a history of malignancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Self-mutilating behaviors, neurological symptoms, and hyperuricemia is characteristic of Lesch-Nyhan Syndrome (LNS). LNS is a rare X-linked recessive disorder caused by a deficiency in the enzyme hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HPRT), which is crucial in the purine salvage pathway.


Ref: Harper 30/e:  p 354-355.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child with a history of recurrent bacterial and viral infections, failure to thrive, developmental delays, and tremors is evaluated. Examination reveals an absence of peripheral lymphoid tissues. Laboratory findings indicate lymphopenia, with normal B-cell counts and immunoglobulin levels. Which enzyme deficiency is most likely responsible for this clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Purine nucleoside phosphorylase

 

Options D.

 

The child has purine nucleoside phosphorylase deficiency, the reason is not yet fully elucidated, specially reduces T-cell counts but not B-cells.

 

Purine nucleoside phosphorylase is one of the salvage enzymes which converts guanosine or inosine to the free base plus ribose-1-phosphate.

 

Explanation:

 

Options A. Hypoxanthine phosphoribosyl transferase deficiency leads to Lesch-Nyhan syndrome, where there is no immune deficiency.

 

Options B. Adenine phosphoribosyl transferase deficiency leads to accumulation of an insoluble metabolite (2, 8-dihydroxyadenine) that precipitates in the kidney ü°™leads to renal failures.

 

Options C. Adenosine deaminase deficiency leads to an immune disorder where both B and T cells are deficient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Purine nucleoside phosphorylase (PNP) deficiency leads to a selective T-cell deficiency, part of the spectrum of SCID disorders. Despite normal B-cell counts and immunoglobulin levels, the lack of T-cell help results in functional impairment of B-cells, leading to recurrent infections.

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/e: p585.
